title: 113_hr4986
content: The "End Operation Choke Point Act of 2014" is cited as the short title. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended to provide business access to insured depository institutions. The Federal banking agencies are prohibited from restricting insured depository institutions from providing products or services to entities that are licensed, registered as a money transmitting business, or have a legal opinion supporting their business legality. Insured depository institutions are not required to provide services to specific entities or regularly review their licensing status. The Federal banking agencies are prohibited from restricting insured depository institutions from providing products or services to entities that are licensed, registered as a money transmitting business, or have a legal opinion supporting their business legality. Insured depository institutions are not required to provide services to specific entities or regularly review their licensing status. The Federal banking agencies may not issue guidance under subsection (a) and any rule implementing subsection (a) must be promulgated in accordance with section 553 of title 5, United States Code. A reasoned legal opinion is defined as a written legal opinion by a State-licensed attorney addressing the facts of a particular business. The attorney's role is to address the legality of a business providing products or services to customers under Federal and State law, tribal ordinances, resolutions, and compacts. This does not include a legal opinion that simply states a conclusion. SEC. 132. BUSINESS ACCESS TO INSURED CREDIT UNIONS. The Board cannot restrict an insured credit union from offering products or services to entities that are licensed, registered as a money transmitting business, and have a legal opinion confirming their legality. Insured credit unions are not required to provide services to any entity or regularly monitor their licensing status. The Board cannot issue guidance under subsection (a) and any rule must be promulgated in accordance with section 553 of title 5, United States Code. A reasoned legal opinion is defined as a written legal opinion by a State-licensed attorney addressing the legality of a business's provision of products. The legality of the business's provision of products or services to customers in relevant jurisdictions under Federal and State law, tribal ordinances, resolutions, and compacts. AMENDMENTS TO THE FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS REFORM, RECOVERY, AND ENFORCEMENT ACT OF 1989. Section 951 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 is amended to allow for court orders to summon witnesses and require the production of relevant records in connection with violations of financial institution laws. The Attorney General can issue court orders to summon witnesses and obtain records for civil proceedings related to financial institution laws. An annual report must be submitted to Congress detailing these court orders. The Attorney General can issue court orders for civil proceedings related to financial institution laws. An annual report to Congress must detail the number of court orders sought, recipients, documents requested, witnesses called to testify, and outcomes of any enforcement actions. SEC. 5. REQUIRING COOPERATION TO DETER THE COMMISSION OF FINANCIAL FRAUD. Section 314 of the USA PATRIOT Act is amended to include the identification of accounts and transactions related to financial fraud. The USA PATRIOT Act is amended to specify that information obtained under Section 314 shall only be used for identifying and reporting on potential terrorist acts, financial fraud, or money laundering. Financial institutions are not required to ensure compliance with licensing requirements for any entity. SEC. 6 amends section 5318(g) of title 31, US Code to specify liability for disclosures in reporting suspicious transactions. SEC. 7 introduces data accountability metrics for the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. Section 310 of title 31, United States Code is amended to include generating feedback and reporting on the utility of data access services to improve cooperation among data providers and users, reduce regulatory burden, and preserve payment system efficiency. The amendment to Section 310 of title 31, United States Code includes adding new paragraphs for monitoring and reporting on access to information in the data maintenance system maintained by FinCEN. This aims to track how the information is used, measure law enforcement outcomes, and ensure accountability while reducing regulatory burdens.
